Award.AwardTitle: Retinoic Acid Signaling induces Ets Repressor proteins to promote primary neurogenesis
Award.AbstractNarration: Cells in developing neural tissue demonstrate an exquisite balance between proliferation (cell growth/division) and differentiation (the specialization of cells into mature neurons). Retinoic acid, an important molecule derived from Vitamin A, is a critical participant in inhibiting cell proliferation and encouraging differentiation. How retinoic acid controls this process to promote the development of mature neurons is not well understood. The Blumberg laboratory identified a gene named ETS2 Repressor Factor (Erf) that plays a key role in neural development. Erf expression is controlled by retinoic acid and loss of retinoic acid or Erf inhibits the formation of neurons. To test how Erf functions downstream of retinoic acid, the Blumberg laboratory will use a molecular approach to inhibit or increase the function of Erf in early embryos and study the expression of important genes involved in the proliferation of neural precursors and in the differentiation of neurons. They expect to identify the molecular pathway through which retinoic acid, Erf and its target genes control the switch between proliferation and differentiation in neural tissue. Unraveling this genetic program and the molecular interactions required for it to function will provide important and broadly applicable details about the proliferation-differentiation switch. This will greatly increase the understanding of how development works and, in particular, how stem cells decide to stop dividing and differentiate into various mature cell types. The broader impacts of this research are in educating and training the next generation of scientists (including women and underrepresented groups) and in disseminating the results of Federally funded science broadly. Furthermore, these studies will benefit society in general by pushing back the frontiers of knowledge regarding a fundamentally important but poorly understood process in Biology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major goal of this research was to identify molecular mechanisms controlling whether immature neural precursors proliferate or instead differentiate into primary neurons. The molecular mechanisms regulating proliferation-differentiation switches are a central, yet poorly understood question in development. Factors that promote cellular proliferation, such as fibroblast growth factors (FGFs) and those that promote differentiation, such as retinoic acid (RA) act in opposition to each other to mediate the balance between proliferation and differentiation that is important for normal development. The intellectual merit is that developing a detailed understanding of molecular interactions underlying the proliferation-differentiation switch will provide insights into fundamental developmental processes regulated by RA such as neuronal differentiation, somitogenesis, dorsoventral and anteroposterior patterning, among others.

 

We previously showed that RA promotes neuronal differentiation whereas blockade of RA signaling inhibits neuronal differentiation but the mechanisms were unknown. Our preliminary studies identified ETS repressor proteins such as ETS repressor factor (ERF) as potential effectors downstream of RA that might regulate the neuronal proliferation-differentiation switch. We found that ERF is induced by RA and opposes the proliferation of neural progenitors, in vivo. ETS repressors such as ERF regulate proliferation-differentiation switches in cell culture models, supporting our hypothesis that they could be important for neuronal differentiation.

 

We investigated where ERF acts during the neurogenic cascade, how RARs modulate ERF expression and activity and what pathways ERF targets to promote neuronal differentiation.  We found that RA acts early in the neurogenic pathway to inhibit expression of neural progenitors by inducing expression of Erf, and the closely related ETS repressor, Etv3/3l. Erf and Etv3/3l act early in the neurogenic cascade to restrain the proliferation of neural precursors. Loss-of-function analysis showed that Erf and Etv3/3l inhibit proliferation of neural progenitors and promote differentiation. Erf/Etv3/3l gain-of-function at gastrula stages (but not at blastula or neurula stages) induced premature neurogenesis. Over-expression of Erf led to an increase in the number of primary neurons; therefore, these RA-induced ETS repressors are key components of the proliferation-differentiation switch during primary neurogenesis. We found that Erf phosphorylation  was critical for its ability to promote primary neurogenesis by inhibiting proliferation of neural progenitors and promoting/supporting their differentiation.

 

We subsequently found that another ETS gene, Etv1/Er81, that is regulated by FGFs, is likely to be repressed by Erf or Etv3/3l to inhibit neural progenitors and promote differentiation.  Loss-of-function studies showed that the expression of cell cycle genes was altered in whole mount in situ hybridization. ER81 loss-of-function led to loss of primary neurons which is secondary to its inhibition of neural induction. We employed hormone-inducible constructs to separate the effects of ER81 on neural induction from its effects on neuronal differentiation. Temporally-controlled ER81 over-expression caused a paucity of neuronal progenitors, and this was rescued by RAR-agonist TTNPB. This line of experimentation successfully linked ER81 to the expansion of neural progenitors.
